review_title: Likely to stay here for a while
job_title: Health Records Technician in Penetanguishene, ON
pros: Great benefits Great starting pay Unionized Culture is overall positive, lots of staff members stay working here for decades
cons: Daily tasks can feel repetitive over time

pros: The property and view is nice.
cons: Toxic workplace. Looks like a good company on paper but policies are only followed if punitive. Widespread workplace bullying and harrassment. Well known by staff and community. This is the "real" reason for the staffing shortage.

review_title: There is no point in working at Waypoint
pros: You could possibly end up in a senior leadership role weeks or months after graduating University. Typically for newer graduates the hourly pay rate is a little higher per hour.
cons: Waypoint is truly the worst employer I have had in my life. Most of my colleagues hated working at Waypoint with most wanting to leave or were counting their years until retirement. There is a lot of turnover of employees at Waypoint. Management has a lot of turnover too. Staffing at Waypoint has been in crisis for decades. When I first starting working there I was shocked to hear of a common practice where leadership would 'order' staff to stay longer because of low staffing numbers. Now, the staffing crisis is so bad at Waypoint they have agency nurses all over the place to fill in the gaps and they still can't get a grasp on staffing levels. The Senior Leadership Team's most observable strategy is negative reinforcement and their competency is lacking considering the staffing issues this hospital has been having for at least 15 years. Do not bring your smartphone to work. You are not allowed! Waypoint continues to keep staff who make verbally abusive comments to other staff. Waypoint has a huge issue with staff bullying other staff and their Senior Leadership have no clue how to navigate this. The Human Resources department is useless to allow the amount of bullying to continue. I also noticed there is a huge lack of expertise in the field of mental health. As a nurse I remember trying to learn more about mental health only to find that most of my colleagues had no clue. The grass is greener on the other side. I'll never work for Waypoint again and the day I quit was one of the best changes I've made in my life.

pros: Good starting pay in the field
cons: Mismanaged institution. Need a revamp of upper management team

pros: Job security, pension, benefits, education fund

review_title: Not a good place to work
pros: Good money, beautiful location on Georgian Bay
cons: There is a huge discrepancy between how they portray themselves to the community (i.e. patient-centered; caring employer) and how they actually "do business" - yes, they treat patient care like a business. It's not about what they can do to make patients better, it's what they can do for the barest of cost. They have little regard for allied health professionals who are seen as "extras" to fill in when nursing staff aren't available, rather than as professional staff who can provide psychotherapeutic treatment. There is a huge and constant turnaround of staff because of this. Not a good place to work if you're a professional individual.

pros: Lots of hours. Higher rate of pay.
cons: Often work understaffed which can lead to risky situations.

review_title: The worst company I have ever worked for!!!
pros: The view of the Bay
cons:
Staffing is a JOKE!  They rely on staff that is already working to stay overtime instead of calling through their list for staff to come in.
Nurse Managers "order" RNs to stay past our 12 hour shift for a total of 16 hours and tell you if you don't you are "abandoning your post" and they will report you to the CNO.  After working the 16 hours they let you leave to drive knowing you could crash and kill yourself on the way home.  They don't care if you are too tired to stay after working a 12 hour shift.
Nepotism is another practice at Waypoint.  Be careful everyone is related!

pros: Pay and Location and Middle management opportunities
cons: Depends on department but typically poor treatment of staff in return staff abuse sick and vacation policies. Emotionally draining place to work.

pros: Great teams when I started
cons: Very poor team building.  No leaders.
